prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "reglet and furniture". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
## The Furniturne

Beware the Furniturne, my son!
The jaws that bite, the claws that catch!
Beware the Reglet-bird, and shun
The frumious Grabbet-snatch!

He took his spurning-knife in hand;
Long time the Furniturne he sought—
So rested he by the Tumtum tree,
And stood a while in thought.

And, as in uffish thought he stood,
The Furniturne, with eyes of flame,
Came whiffling through the tillered wood,
And burbled as it came!

One, two! One, two! And through and through
The spurning-knife went snicker-snack!
It left it dead, and with its head
He went galumphing back.

“And hast thou slain the Furniturne?
Come to my arms, my beamish boy!
O frabjous day! Callooh! Callay!”
He chortled in his joy.

Beware the Furniturne, my son!
The jaws that bite, the claws that catch!
Beware the Reglet-bird, and shun
The frumious Grabbet-snatch!
label: high

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "blued screw in a movement". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Blued Screw's Scrabble

The blued screw, now gliddering, slonched in the groove,
With whizzle and whumpha, it twiddled astray.
"Beware the strange turnings, my son, and behoove
The clumphing of gears as they jigger and play!"

He fingered his wrench-spanner, polished and bright,
His oil-rags all sprockled, his visgrick so keen.
He charted the casing by moon-glint and light,
And hummed a low tune to the whirring machine.

And the blued screw, a-jostle, came blizzaring by,
With gnashing of threads and a grindery drone.
It slurped and it clanked with a terrible cry,
And hummered its way from the piston and cone.

One snickt! One quick twist with the wrench-spanner's might!
The blued screw went whaffsical, tumbled and fell.
It lay there, quite dummered, bereft of its flight,
Its movement unwound from its mystical spell.

"And hast thou then whumbled the blued screw, my son?
Come to my arm, for the turning is done!"
The blued screw, now gliddering, on a shelf it lay,
With whizzle and whumpha, it screeched no more, nay.
label: high
judge_raw:

<C4_think>Rhyme: Lines 2 and 4 rhyme or slant rhyme clearly in 4 of 5 stanzas (80%); no evidence of dominant AABB pattern</C4_think>
<C5_think>Ring composition: Final stanza reuses “blued screw, now gliddering” phrase and similar “whizzle and whumpha” phrase echoing the first stanza’s opening line - at least two repeated content words/phrases</C5_think>
<C6_think>Warning/admonition: Present in stanza 2 with "Beware the strange turnings, my son," — a caution/admonition</C6_think>
<C7_think>Preparation: Present in stanza 3 with protagonist preparing wrench-spanner, oil-rags, charting casing, humming— clear preparatory resolve and tool readiness before confrontation</C7_think>
<C8_think>Encounter: Present in stanza 4 where blued screw comes jostling by with noise and cry, described as adversarial event</C8_think>
<C9_think>Slaying/decisive act: Present in stanza 5 with "One snickt! One quick twist" and blued screw falling, movement unwound - clear resolution via decisive action</C9_think>
<C10_think>Return/celebration: In final stanza 6, speaker invites son to arm, acknowledges action done; although shorter, it expresses completion and acknowledgement—mostly fits celebration/return function</C10_think>
<C11_think>Coinages: Distinct coinages like "blued screw," "gliddering," "slonched," "whizzle," "whumpha," "clumphing," "jigger," "sprockled," "visgrick," "blizzaring," "grindery," "whaffsical," "dummered," and "whumbled" tally well over 8 distinct invented words</C11_think>
<C12_think>Each stanza contains at least one coinage (e.g., blued screw, gliddering, whizzle, whumpha, clumphing, sprockled, visgrick, blizzaring, grindery, whaffsical, dummered, whumbled) present continuously</C12_think>

<C15_think>Alliteration/consonance: Stanzas like 1 (“blued screw, now gliddering, slonched in the groove”), 2 (“son, and behoove / clumphing of gears as they jigger and play”), and 3 (“wrench-spanner, polished and bright; oil-rags all sprockled; visgrick so keen”) show clear within-line alliteration or consonance beyond incidental repeats in at least two stanzas</C15_think>
<C16_think>Arc order matches canonical sequence: warning/admonition -> preparation -> encounter -> decisive action -> return/celebration seen clearly in order</C16_think>
<C17_think>No lines verbatim copied from canonical poem; all original phrasing and new coinages</C17_think>
<C18_think>Canonical token budget is low; only “Beware”, “son”, and structure echo are reminiscent but no canonical proper nouns or iconic words like “vorpal,” “Jubjub,” etc.</C18_think>
<C19_think>Syllable pattern aligns with Jabberwocky style: longer lines ~8-9 syllables, shorter lines ~5-7, consistently across all quatrain stanzas</C19_think>
<C20_think>Rhyme variety: Rhyme endings vary stanza to stanza, no end-word repeated more than twice for (2,4) rhyme in the full poem excluding ring repetition</C20_think>
<C21_think>Lexical repetition: No single content word overused >5 times or above ~8% threshold; varied vocabulary throughout</C21_think>
<C22_think>Coinage variety: Coinages have multiple distinct roots and forms, no single suffix or root dominates over 50% usage, showing diversity</C22_think>
<C23_think>Topic adherence: The poem clearly addresses a mechanical adversary “blued screw” in a fantasy battle style, aligned with Jabberwocky’s theme of a dangerous foe and heroic overcoming</C23_think>

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "murmuration over stubble". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
## The Murmuration

The stubble-fields, all crisp and brown, did lie;
Each stalklet stiff, where reapers long had been.
'Beware the Swirl-Winge, Son! Its shadow nigh,
And if you see it, then you've truly seen!'

He donned his gaiters, buttoned up with care,
And packed his flask with something stout and strong.
A humdrum twig, a bit of ancient prayer,
To ward off what his father warned was wrong.

And as he plodded, through the rustling stalks,
A flitting darkness, veered from out the blue!
With whirring, whizzing, dizzy, silent talks,
The Swirl-Winge writhed, a shifting, living hue!

It corkscrewed, dipped, a thousand specks as one,
In ebbless flow, a cloud of feathered might.
He stood his ground, beneath the setting sun,
And shook his twig, with all his main and light.

Then, with a shudder, the dark form withdrew,
Like ink un-spilled, it melted from the sight.
He ambled home, his weary journey through,
And slept until the very morning light.
label: medium
judge_raw:
<think>
<C1_think>There is a title line ("## The Murmuration") before the first stanza, non-empty and separate.</C1_think>
<C2_think>The poem has 6 stanzas, all are quatrains (4 lines each), so stanza count within 5-8 inclusive and all quatrains -> yes.</C2_think>
<C3_think>Examining alternating longer/shorter lines with ≥2 content-word difference: pattern is inconsistent. Some stanzas show small variation, but not clearly alternating longer/shorter for ≥60% of stanzas. More uniform line lengths and no clear alternation evident -> no.</C3_think>
<C4_think>Rhyme in lines 2 and 4 per stanza: stanza 1 rhyme ("been" / "seen"), stanza 2 ("care"/"wrong" no rhyme), stanza 3 ("stalks"/"talks") rhyme, stanza 4 ("one"/"sun") rhyme, stanza 5 ("withdrew"/"sight") no rhyme, stanza 6 ("through"/"light") rhyme. So 4/6 stanzas rhyme 2/4 = ~66%, passes threshold. No obvious AABB dominance; rhymes fairly mixed -> yes.</C4_think>
<C5_think>Final stanza does not echo the opening with ≥2 repeated content words/phrases or clear refrain; setting and imagery different; no ring echo -> no.</C5_think>
<C6_think>In stanza 1, an admonition is clearly given: 'Beware the Swirl-Winge, Son!' -> yes.</C6_think>
<C7_think>There is a clear preparation before the encounter: protagonist dons gaiters, packs flask, carries a twig and prayer as protection -> yes.</C7_think>
<C8_think>Clear encounter in stanza 4: "A flitting darkness... The Swirl-Winge writhed" describes a meeting with the adversary -> yes.</C8_think>
<C9_think>Decisive action: shaking the twig at the creature (stanza 5) causing it to withdraw is a clear action resolving tension -> yes.</C9_think>
<C10_think>No explicit return celebration or jubilant acknowledgement; last stanza depicts going home and sleeping but no joy/reward expressed -> no.</C10_think>
<C11_think>Coinages present include: Swirl-Winge, stalklet, main (used archaically?), ebbless, but total distinct coinages are fewer than 8 (most words are real English, no many invented words). Less than threshold -> no.</C11_think>
<C12_think>Most stanzas except maybe last have no clear coinage; coinage spread is uneven and not each stanza includes a coinage. (Swirl-Winge mainly in first and fourth stanza.) -> no.</C12_think>

<C14_think>Onomatopoeia: "whirring, whizzing" could count as onomatopoeic bursts; "shook his twig" no; only one clear onomatopoeic cluster present; requirements is ≥2 bursts. Uncertain but likely insufficient -> no.</C14_think>
